responses: The contamination event occurred in December 2002 and January 2003, a duration of 59 days.
Soderhamn municipality

The outbreaks of Campylobacter and acute gastroenteritis (AGI) in Soderhamn municipality were associated with consumption of communal water (CW). Both outbreaks occurred simultaneously, with a rapid assessment indicating that 24% of the population self-reported AGI, potentially affecting some 6-7000 members of the population. Water sampling revealed the presence of Campylobacter in stool and Escherichia coli (E. coli) from routine communal water samples. The method used strengthened epidemiological evidence and was efficient in the use of time and resources.
The text does not specify what triggered the contamination event.
The investigation found that the outbreaks were associated with consumption of communal water (CW). Campylobacter was detected in stool, environmental, and water samples.
The contamination event was first discovered through a routine water sample analysis that detected one E. coli in a well water sample two weeks prior to the investigation.
The investigation found that 24% of the population self-reported AGI, potentially affecting some 6-7000 members of the population.
The number of people who fell ill due to the event was 24% of the population, potentially affecting some 6-7000 members of the population.
The attack rate of AGI was 27.3% among those who consumed water, compared to 12% among those who did not consume water.
The study did not provide information on the number of fatalities associated with the contamination event.
Campylobacter and Escherichia coli (E. coli) were found in stool, environmental, and water samples.
The study found that diarrhea, abdominal cramps, nausea, vomiting, fever, headache, and myalgia were associated with the contamination.

The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included intensification of water sampling, chlorination of the water supplies of the municipality, and holding a press conference to inform the population.

The investigation included:

1. Intensification of water sampling
2. Chlorination of the water supplies of the municipality
3. Holding a press conference to inform the population
4. Epidemiological investigations (a case-cohort study and a retrospective cohort study) to identify the role of the water supply and other risk factors in both outbreaks.
The case definition for the cohort study was defined as a person living in the Soderhamn municipality during December 2002 and January 2003 with self-diagnosed acute gastrointestinal illness (AGI).
Risk factors identified during the investigation included consumption of communal water (OR = 12.6, 95% CI: 1.7-92.3) and amount of water consumed (AR = 27.3%, 95% CI: 12%).
The contamination event spanned a period of 59 days, from December 1st, 2002 to January 28th, 2003.

Immediate measures of intervention included intensification of water sampling; chlorination of the water supplies of the municipality; and holding a press conference to inform the population. No advice on boiling water was issued.

Water analyses performed during the monitoring phase included testing for Campylobacter and Escherichia coli (E. coli) in stool, environmental, and water samples using standard methods at Gavle Hospital and SMI laboratories respectively.
Campylobacter and Escherichia coli (E. coli)

The following steps were taken to restore the system after some time passed:

* Intensification of water sampling
* Chlorination of the water supplies of the municipality
* Holding a press conference to inform the population

Note: The text does not mention any other steps taken to restore the system after some time passed.

Prevention measures that have been implemented include intensification of water sampling, chlorination of the water supplies of the municipality, and holding a press conference to inform the population about the outbreak. No advice on boiling water was issued.

responses: The contamination event occurred between 29th February and 9th April 2016.
Bwikhonge Sub-county, Bulambuli District, Eastern Uganda

The cholera outbreak started on 29 February in Bwikhonge Sub-county, Bulambuli District in Eastern Uganda. The initial control measures were implemented, but in late March, cases sharply increased in Bwikhonge Sub-county. V. cholerae was isolated in 2 of the 7 river water samples collected from different locations. The index case in Bwikhonge Sub-county had onset on 29 February but the outbreak had been ongoing in the neighboring sub-counties in the previous 3 months.
The text does not provide information on what triggered the contamination event.
The investigation found that the contamination source was Cheptui River water.

The contamination event was first discovered through active case finding by visiting all parishes in Bwikhonge Sub-county with the help of members of community health workers, and updating the line-list. Using a standardized case investigation form, we interviewed 40 case-patients conveniently found at the cholera treatment centre and the community about their histories of food and water intake and practices during the possible exposure period.
The text does not provide information on the number of individuals affected by the contaminant.
The total number of suspected cases was 108, with 7 confirmed cases.
The attack rate for this cholera outbreak was 1.3% (108/8404).
The text does not provide information on the number of fatalities associated with the cholera outbreak in Bwikhonge Sub-county, Bulambuli District, Eastern Uganda.
Vibrio cholerae was isolated from 2 of the 7 river water samples collected from different locations.
The following symptoms were associated with the contamination: sudden onset of watery diarrhea.

The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included:

1. Defining a suspected case as sudden onset of watery diarrhea from 1 March 2016 onwards in a resident of Bulambuli District.
2. Conducting a case-control study involving 100 suspected case-patients and 100 asymptomatic controls, individually-matched by residence village and age.
3. Collecting seven water samples for laboratory testing.

The investigation involved a case-control study of 100 suspected cases and 100 asymptomatic controls, individually matched by residence village and age. Water samples were collected from different sources, including Cheptui River and borehole pumps, and tested for V. cholerae using bacteriological culture identification. The investigation also included active case finding, line-list review, and interviewing of case-patients and controls about their water intake history and practices during the possible exposure period.
The case definition used for the cohort study was: "A suspected case was defined as sudden onset of watery diarrhea from 1 March 2016 onwards in a resident of Bulambuli District."
Risk factors identified during the investigation included drinking contaminated water from Cheptui River.
The outbreak started on 29 February and lasted until 9 April, a total of 31 days.

Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of contamination included:

* Boiling of water before consumption was advised by the local public health authorities.
* Water supply from Cheptui River was stopped by the local authorities.
* Chlorination of water sources was carried out by the local authorities.

The following water analyses were performed during the monitoring phase:

1. Bacteriological culture identification of V. cholerae.
2. Testing for antimicrobial susceptibility using modified Kirby-Bauer disk diffusion method.
V. cholerae

The following steps were taken to restore the system after some time passed:

1. Boiling and/or treating drinking water
2. Improved sanitation
3. Distribution of chlorine tablets to the affected villages
4. Construction of more borehole pumps.

The following measures were implemented to prevent future contamination events:

1. Boiling and/or treating drinking water from Cheptui River before consumption.
2. Improved sanitation, including construction of more borehole pumps.
3. Distribution of chlorine tablets to the affected villages.

responses: The contamination event occurred in September 2000.
The contamination event took place in a service reservoir located on a hillside housing estate in South Wales.

The outbreak occurred in an economically deprived housing estate located in South Wales, UK. The contamination event was caused by a crack in the wall of the holding reservoir that supplied mains water to the upper part of the estate. Surface water from nearby pasture land likely entered the reservoir through the crack, contaminating the water supply.
The crack in the wall of the holding reservoir was identified as the likely cause of the contamination event.
The likely cause of this outbreak was identified as a crack in the wall of the holding reservoir that supplied mains water to the upper estate.
The crack in the wall of the holding reservoir was identified as the likely cause of the outbreak.
The outbreak affected 802 individuals, of which 49 lived in the upper estate.
The number of people who fell ill due to the event was 15.

The attack rate for those resident in the upper estate was 232/802 (29.0%) compared with 1152 G. Richardson and others 49/413 (11.9%) for those in the lower estate [relative risk (RR) 2.44, 95% confidence interval (CI) 1.83-3.24, P<0.001].
The text does not provide information on fatality count associated with the contamination event.
Campylobacter jejuni
Diarrhoeal illness (o3 stools within 24 h) lasting over 1 day in September 2000.

Initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included:

1. Identification of a crack in the wall of the holding reservoir.
2. Sampling of the service reservoir supplying the upper estate on random days by the water company.
3. Daily sampling of the service reservoir supplying the upper estate from 30 September by the water company.
4. Physical external inspection of the reservoir on 2 October and one compartment of the reservoir was taken out of service for internal inspection.
5. Rainfall records for the area, maintained by the national Meteorological Office, were obtained.

The investigation included a retrospective cohort study of diarrheal illness in estate residents, a nested case-control study of laboratory-confirmed cases and controls, bacteriological sampling of the service reservoir, and inspection of the reservoir for cracks or other defects.
The case definition used for the cohort study was an individual residing on the estate, with diarrhoeal illness (o3 stools within 24 h) lasting over 1 day in September 2000.

Risk factors identified during the investigation included:

1. Water consumption (OR 18, 95% CI 3.5-92.4 for heaviest consumers, x2 trend P<0.0001)
2. Residence in the upper estate (PAR 49%, RR 2.44, 95% CI 1.83-3.24)
The contamination event spanned from September 17 to September 24, 2000.

Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination included:

* Boil water advisory: Issued for the upper estate residents to boil their tap water before consumption.
* Stopping water supply: The water supply to the upper estate was temporarily stopped until further notice.
* Chlorination: Increased chlorination of the service reservoir supplying the upper estate was carried out to reduce the risk of further contamination.

Water analyses performed during the monitoring phase included bacteriological and chlorination records of weekly sampling of the service reservoir, daily sampling of the service reservoir for indicator organisms (coliforms and E. coli), free and total chlorine levels, and additional analyses for faecal streptococci and clostridia.
Campylobacters.
The service reservoir was repaired and permanent booster chlorination facilities commissioned on 29 November 2000.

The following measures were implemented to prevent future contamination events:

1. Regular inspection and maintenance of service reservoirs, including weekly sampling of the outlet supplying the upper estate.
2. Installation of permanent booster chlorination facilities to ensure adequate disinfection of water supplied to the upper estate.
3. Training for water company staff on the identification and management of potential contamination sources.
4. Enhanced surveillance and monitoring of water quality, including regular testing for indicator organisms and faecal streptococci.

* <=4 years: 40%
* >=65 years: 13.4%

responses: The text does not provide a specific date for when the contamination event occurred.
Eagle-Vail, Colorado

The community waterborne nonbacterial gastroenteritis outbreak occurred in Eagle-Vail, Colorado in March 1981. Illness (defined as vomiting and/or diarrhea) was statistically associated with water consumption. Five of seven persons associated with the outbreak were infected with rotavirus as shown by virus detection or serological methods.

The upstream Vail Water & Sanitation District sewage treatment plant could not handle the load being presented to it and was discharging sludge solids into Gore Creek, upstream from the Eagle River water intake for the Eagle-Vail plant.
Rotavirus was identified as the source of contamination.

The outbreak of gastrointestinal illness described here was clearly waterborne and was initially approached as a fairly routine Norwalk-like outbreak. It may have been associated with rotavirus, however.
The text states that 128 residents were reached, with 56 (43.8 per cent) having been ill in the previous 30 days with diarrhea (three or more loose stools per day) and/or vomiting.
The number of people who fell ill due to the event was 56 (43.8 per cent) out of 128 residents.

The attack rate for diarrhea and/or vomiting during the epidemic period was closely related to amount of tap water consumption with a x2 for linear trend of 7.07, p = .0039 (Table 1). Overall attack rate was 41/128 (32.0 per cent). Those who drank no tap water drank bottled water for the most part. The relative risk for those who drank one or more glasses of tap water a day compared to those who drank no tap water was 2.18 (95 per cent confidence interval 1.10-4.32).
The text does not provide information on fatality count associated with the contamination event.
Rotavirus was identified as a pathogen in the collected samples.
Diarrhea, vomiting, cramping, fever

The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included:

1. Telephone contact with the principal medical facility serving the five communities described above showed that office and emergency-room visits for gastrointestinal disease had risen sharply March 6-11; review of emergency room records showed that the increase was entirely in residents of Eagle-Vail and Avon, not of Vail itself or the other two communities in the service area of the medical facility.
2. A household telephone survey was performed on March 13 and 14 by calling every 6th listed residential number in a three-digit telephone exchange until 48 households were reached; about 80 households in the sample did not answer on multiple attempts in a 24-hour period, and 20 were disconnected.
3. Laboratory records of the Vail Mountain Medical Center for the period March 6-25, 1981 were reviewed.

The detailed investigation included a survey of 128 residents in the affected area, including questions about their recent illnesses, water consumption habits, and social events attended. The survey also included laboratory tests for viral antibodies and rotavirus particles in stool samples. Additionally, the water treatment plant at Eagle-Vail and the sewage treatment plant at Vail were inspected to identify any potential sources of contamination.
The case definition used for the cohort study is diarrhea (three or more loose stools per day) and/or vomiting (at least once per day).

Risk factors identified during the investigation included:

1. Amount of tap water consumption
2. Age (over 2 years old)
The contamination event spanned from March 6-13, 1981.
Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination included issuing a boil water advisory for the affected area and stopping the water supply to the community.

Waterborne gastroenteritis outbreaks have been associated with Salmonella (including typhi), Shigella, Campylobacter, hepatitis A, Giardia lamblia, Entameba histolytica, Norwalk virus,1,2 a similar virus, the Snow Mountain Agent,3 and other agents.
Rotavirus.

The following steps were taken to restore the system after some time passed:

1. Emergency repairs to the Eagle-Vail water treatment plant.
2. Improvements to ensure a reliable safe water supply.
3. Increased storage for treated water.
4. A third filter.
5. Chemical treatment before filtration.

Rotavirus should be looked for as a cause of waterborne outbreaks. Waterborne gastroenteritis outbreaks have been associated with Salmonella (including typhi), Shigella, Campylobacter, hepatitis A, Giardia lamblia, Entameba histolytica, Norwalk virus,1,2 a similar virus, the Snow Mountain Agent,3 and other agents.

The age demographics of the individuals mentioned in the text are as follows:

* Over 80% of the residents were adults.
* All but five residents were over two years old.
* Only a handful were over age 50.

responses: The contamination event occurred between 11-13 October 1996.
The contamination event took place in the water distribution system.
The contamination event was caused by the groundwater contamination of the community water system, which led to the isolation of Shigella sonnei from both water samples and faeces of patients.
Groundwater contamination
The source of the contamination was groundwater from a single borehole used by the community water system.

The contamination event was first discovered on the second day of the outbreak (13 October) when the Laboratory of Hygiene collected a 1-l sample from the pumping station and tested it for the presence of Salmonella and Shigella using an enrichment technique with sterile 0-1% peptone water.

The article states that "at least 288 cases of gastro-enteritis in the community of Eleoussa between 11 and 22 October, an attack rate of 13.4%." Therefore, the answer to the user's question is: 288 individuals were affected by the contaminant.
The number of people who fell ill due to the event was 288.
The attack rate for this outbreak was 13.4%. This means that for every 100 individuals exposed, 13.4 individuals became ill.
Fatality Count: Not specified.
Shigella sonnei was isolated from both, water samples and faeces of patients.
The symptoms associated with the contamination were diarrhea, vomiting, fever, headache, and abdominal pain.

The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event were:
- Collected three samples from the water distribution system, one sample from the tank, and one sample from the pumping station on the first day after the outbreak had been recognized (11 October 1996).
- On 13 October a 1-l sample was collected from the pumping station.

The investigation included collecting water samples from the distribution system, tank, and pumping station on day 1 (11 October) and day 3 (13 October). The samples were tested for total and faecal coliforms using the membrane filtration method. Additionally, a 1-l sample was collected from the pumping station on day 3 and was filtered and tested for the presence of Salmonella and Shigella using an enrichment technique with sterile 0-1% peptone water. Serological identification was performed using slide agglutination technique with Shigella antisera (polyvalent and type-specific sera).
The case definition for the cohort study was based on self-reported illness in patients suffering from gastro-enteritis, as recorded by local authorities and healthcare professionals.

Risk factors identified during the investigation include:
Age group 0-14 years (41.4%)
Age group over 65 years (P<0.05)
The contamination event spanned from 11-22 October 1996.
Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination included an immediate chlorination of the water-distribution system and the tank.

The following types of water analyses were performed during the monitoring phase:

* Total and faecal coliforms using the membrane filtration method
* Presence of salmonella and shigella using an enrichment technique with sterile 0-1% peptone water.
* Serological identification was performed using the slide agglutination technique with shigella antisera (polyvalent and type-specific sera)
Shigella sonnei

1. Immediate chlorination of the water-distribution system and the tank.

responses: The contamination event occurred in September 2018.
Brescia province, northern Italy

The outbreak occurred in September 2018 in Brescia province, northern Italy, and affected 33 cases (two fatal) residing in seven municipalities along the Chiese river. Legionella pneumophila serogroup 2 (Lp2) was identified as the causative agent, and environmental investigation revealed that 533 water samples were collected, of which only three samples, all collected from the Chiese river, were Lp2 ST1455.
The text does not provide information on what triggered the contamination event.
The source of contamination was identified as the Chiese river.
The outbreak was detected when a sudden increase of LD cases was reported in Brescia province, most notably in seven municipalities located along the Chiese river.
The outbreak affected 88 individuals who were identified with at least one positive diagnostic test (UAT, culture, real-time PCR, or serology (seroconversion or single high titre)).
The number of people who fell ill due to the event was 33.
The attack rate for this outbreak was 6.4% (34/533).
Two fatalities were associated with the contamination event.
Lp2 (Legionella pneumophila serogroup 2) was identified in 34 of the 533 water samples collected, all from the Chiese river.
The symptoms associated with the contamination were pneumonia.

The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included:

1. Environmental investigation was undertaken immediately after the outbreak was reported, and water samples were collected from private homes, municipal water systems, cooling towers, and the river Chiese.
2. Water sample culturing was performed according to International Organization for Standardization (ISO) 11731:2017, using a detection limit of 100 colony-forming units ((CFU)/L).

The local health personnel inspected a large number of possible sources located in the Brescia province, particularly in the municipalities located along the Chiese river. Water samples (1L) were collected from drinking water taps of cases' homes, shopping centres, healthcare facilities, business and public buildings, from basin and circulating water of cooling towers of industrial sites and from wells and pipes of the municipal water network.

The case definition used for the cohort study was based on the EU case definition, which requires at least one diagnostic test (UAT, culture, real-time PCR, or serology) to confirm the diagnosis of Legionnaires' disease.
Risks factors identified during the investigation included diabetes, cardiopathy, or chronic, autoimmune or immunosuppressive diseases.
The outbreak occurred between the end of August and the first half of October 2018 (Figure 1).

Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination included:

* Boiling water advisory was issued for the affected areas.
* Water supply was stopped in the affected municipalities.
* Chlorination of the water supply was increased to reduce the risk of Legionella growth.
Water samples were collected from private homes, municipal water systems, cooling towers, and the river Chiese. Overall, 533 environmental water samples were analyzed and 34 were positive for Lp.
Lp (Legionella pneumophila)

The following steps were taken to restore the system after some time passed:

1. Disinfection of all industrial and non-industrial plants that might give rise to aerosols was requested.
2. A correct use of the Chiese river water was recommended, taking into account periods of drought and guaranteeing the minimum vital flow for the ecological balance of the river itself.
The local health authority decided to enact a regional law aimed at implementing a mandatory notification of cooling towers, as recommended by the national Legionella guidelines.

The age demographics of the individuals mentioned in the text are as follows:

* Median age of cases: 60.6 years (range: 19-91 years)
* Ratio of men to women: 2.4:1 (62/26)

Harnes, France

The investigation found that plant A was the source of the outbreak, with Legionella pneumophila strain Lens isolated from cooling towers, wastewater, and air samples. The unique strain matched all 23 clinical isolates. Modeling of atmospheric dispersion of aerosols emitted from plant A's cooling towers showed good coverage of the affected communes, and no other aerosol-producing installation was identified as a plausible source.

The investigation found that plant A was the most likely source of the contamination.

The contamination event was first discovered when routine self-sampling detected high levels of Legionella bacteria in the cooling towers of a petrochemical plant (plant A) in Harnes on 28 November 2003.
The investigation found that at least 18,000 individuals were exposed to the contaminated aerosols emitted from plant A's cooling towers.
The number of people who fell ill due to the event was 86.
The attack rate for residents of the 22 affected communes was 3.9/10,000 population, which was 120 times higher than the national incidence rate in 2003 (0.18/10,000 population).
Eighteen (21%) of 86 laboratory-confirmed cases were fatal.
Legionella pneumophila serogroup 1 (Lp-1) was isolated from cooling towers, wastewater, and air samples from plant A.
The following symptoms were associated with the contamination: pneumonia, radiologically confirmed, laboratory evidence of infection with Legionella pneumophila serogroup 1 (Lp-1).

The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included routine self-sampling detecting high levels of Legionella bacteria in the cooling towers of a petrochemical plant (plant A) in Harnes, France on November 28, 2003.

The following details of the investigation were provided:

* Case definition and case investigation: A confirmed case of LD was defined as a person who (1) had radiologically confirmed pneumonia and laboratory evidence of infection with Legionella pneumophila serogroup 1 (Lp-1) (i.e., isolation of Lp-1 from respiratory secretions, detection of Lp-1 antigens in urine, or a minimum of a 4-fold increase [to 128] in antibody titers to Lp-1), (2) became ill between 1 November 2003 and 31 January 2004, and (3) lived in or visited Harnes or its neighboring communes during the 10 days before the illness. Persons who had been hospitalized or traveling continuously outside of the community during the 10 days before the illness were excluded.
* Matched case-control study: On 15 January 2004, a matched case-control study was initiated to identify risk factors related to personal characteristics, activities, and potential exposure to contaminated aerosols. Confirmed cases living in communes where at least 2 cases had been identified were included in the study. Controls were randomly selected from the municipal electoral list. Three controls were matched to each case, according to commune of residence, age (10-year groups), and sex.
* Environmental investigation: Household water from cases' homes was systematically sampled. Locations of CTs and other industrial cooling systems in the epidemic zone were obtained from a census performed by the local environmental authority. Site inspections, record reviews, and water sampling were performed on these installations, as well as on other potential sources of contamination. These included municipal portable water systems, wastewater treatment plants, wells, canals, decorative fountains, air-conditioning systems in public buildings, car-wash stations, and other installations/devices capable of aerosol dissemination. Preventive decontamination was subsequently performed on installations that had levels of Legionella bacteria >100 cfu/L. Weekly control sample collection was performed on all CTs until 15 February. Air samples were collected using a prototype of microbial air sampler (Cyclone; CSTB).
* Microbiological investigation: Diagnostic tests at the local hospitals included a urinary antigen test for Lp-1 (Now Legionella; Binax) [21], culture, and an indirect immunofluorescence test for serum antibody against L. pneumophila [22]. Legionella bacteria were isolated from environmental samples in accordance with the standard AFNOR NFT90-431 procedure [23] and were identified to the species and serogroup level by direct immunofluorescence and random amplified polymorphic DNA polymerase chain reaction [24]. All clinical and environmental isolates of Lp-1 and a selection of environmental isolates of L. pneumophila serogroups 2-15 were analyzed using the pulsed-field gel electrophoresis-SfiI method [25].
* Modeling of aerosol dispersion: A Gaussian dispersion model, ADMS 3 [26], was used to simulate the dispersion of presumably infectious aerosols from the CTs of plant A. The flat topography of the area allowed the model to simulate the aerosol dispersion on a horizontal scale over the epidemic zone on the basis of the following parameters: the emission parameters of plant A (including CT configuration, capacity, mode of function, and cleaning operations) and hourly meteorological data during the corresponding period (temperature, humidity, nebulosity, and wind speed and direction). Geographical information systems analysis was performed in ArcMap (version 8.3; ESRI).

The case definition used for the cohort study was a confirmed case of Legionnaires' disease as follows: (1) had radiologically confirmed pneumonia and laboratory evidence of infection with Legionella pneumophila serogroup 1 (Lp-1) (i.e., isolation of Lp-1 from respiratory secretions, detection of Lp-1 antigens in urine, or a minimum of a 4-fold increase [to 128] in antibody titers to Lp-1), (2) became ill between 1 November 2003 and 31 January 2004, and (3) lived in or visited Harnes or its neighboring communes during the 10 days before the illness.
Smoking, silicosis, and spending 1100 min outdoors daily were identified as risk factors for acquiring legionnaires' disease during the investigation.
The contamination event spanned from November 2003 to January 2004 (3 months).

Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination included:

* Boiling water advisory: The local authorities issued a boiling water advisory for all households in the affected areas, recommending that residents boil their tap water before consumption.
* Stopping water supply: The water supply to the affected areas was temporarily stopped to prevent further contamination of the water network.
* Chlorination: Chlorine was added to the water supply to kill any remaining Legionella bacteria.
Water analyses performed during the monitoring phase included household water sampling from cases' homes.

3. Environmental risk assessment of operation and control measures implemented at the plant was conducted.

responses: The contamination event occurred in May 2007.
Wuxi, Jiangsu Province, China

The drinking water crisis in Wuxi, China in 2007 was caused by a massive bloom of toxin-producing cyanobacteria Microcystis spp. in Lake Taihu, which is the city's sole water supply. The bloom accumulated at the shoreline near the water plant's intake, causing contamination of the drinking water. The severity of the contamination was attributed to excessive nutrient enrichment, but a multi-annual warming trend extended the bloom period and amplified its severity. The management action of diverting water from the nearby Yangtze River exacerbated the problem by transporting the bloom into the intake. The contaminated drinking water affected approximately 2 million people who regularly use the city's water supply.
The text states that the drinking water contamination was triggered by an unusually warm spring.
The origin of the contamination was identified as the northeast part of Gonghu Bay, where the bloom originated from.

The drinking water crisis affected approximately 2 million people who regularly use the city's water supply.

The investigation included collecting water samples from around the intake by boat on June 1, 2007, and analyzing their chemical composition. The samples were taken at different locations to determine if there were any spatial patterns in the contamination. Additionally, the study examined the spatial distribution of CODMn, TN, and TP concentrations in Gonghu Bay on June 3, 2007.

Risk factors identified during the investigation included excessive nutrient enrichment, a multi-annual warming trend, unanticipated negative impacts of water management, and climatic factors controlling these blooms and their impacts on water supply in this and other large lakes threatened by accelerating eutrophication.
The contamination event spanned from May 29, 2007 to June 5, 2007, a total of 7 days.

Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination included issuing a boil water advisory for residents in Wuxi, stopping the intake of water from Lake Taihu, and increasing chlorination levels in the water supply.

The following steps were taken to restore the system after some time passed:

1. Diverted water from nearby Yangtze River to flush the lake of the bloom.
2. Used chemicals to control the growth of cyanobacteria.

The study suggests that long-term management of large lakes like Taihu must consider both human and climatic factors controlling cyanobacterial blooms and their impacts on water supply. This includes reducing excessive nutrient enrichment, improving water circulation, and implementing multi-annual warming trend management strategies to reduce the severity of blooms. Additionally, monitoring and early warning systems can be established to detect cyanobacterial blooms and prevent contamination events.

responses: The outbreak occurred in June 2014.
The outbreak occurred at a private college in northwest China.

The outbreak occurred in June 2014 at a private college in northwest China, involving 629 students (range: 17-27 years, average 21.3 years) and two teachers. The main symptoms included non-bloody watery diarrhea, stomach ache, nausea, and vomiting, and the duration of illness ranged from 1 to 7 days. Eight of 18 water samples were disqualified. Thirty-four norovirus (NoV) RNA-positive samples were identified from 48 stool-related samples, including four GII.6, five GI.6, four GI.3, and three GI.1 genotypes. The risk ratios associated with wells one and two were 1.66 and 1.49, respectively, and the RR associated with living in north dormitory building one was 2.59.
The text does not provide information on what triggered the contamination event.

The risk ratios (RRs) associated with wells one and two were 1.66 and 1.49, respectively, and the RR associated with living in north dormitory building one was 2.59. These results suggested that NoV-contaminated water might be the origin of this outbreak.
The outbreak was first detected on June 1, 2014, when 34 norovirus (NoV) RNA-positive samples were identified from 48 stool-related samples.
The study reported that a total of 629 students (range: 17-27 years, average 21.3 years) were affected by the outbreak, including 8 teachers.
The total number of people who fell ill due to the outbreak was 629.
The attack rate for this outbreak was 25.6% (95% CI: 18.4-33.7%).
The study reported 8 fatalities associated with the outbreak.

The following pathogens were identified in the collected samples:

* Norovirus (NoV)
* Enteropathogenic Escherichia coli (EPEC)
* Enteroadherent Escherichia coli (EAEC)
* Shigella
* Campylobacter
* Yersinia enterocolitica
Symptoms associated with the contamination included non-bloody watery diarrhea, stomach ache, nausea, and vomiting.

The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included:

1. Conducting an epidemiological survey of patients, including recording onset dates, symptoms, duration of illness, and eating and drinking history.
2. Implementing environmental surveillance, including examination of local wells, buildings, and cafeterias.
3. Collecting water samples from the affected area for laboratory testing.
4. Conducting bacterial detection in water and stool specimens.
5. Performing nucleic acid detection of diarrheogenic Escherichia coli in water and fecal samples.
6. Detecting virus presence in water and fecal samples using commercial kits.
7. Genotyping NoV GI/GII and astroviruses using PCR.

The following details of the investigation were recorded:

* Water samples were collected from wells 1, 2, and 3 on June 11, 2014, and bacterial detection was performed using commercial real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) kits.
* Bacterial detection in water and stool specimens: Aerobic bacterial count, total coliforms, and thermotolerant coliforms were measured according to the national standards for drinking water quality of China (GB5750-2006).
* Nucleic acid detection of diarrheogenic Escherichia coli: Commercial real-time PCR assays were employed to test for nucleic acids of diarrheogenic E. coli by commercial kits (DD0091-95, Shanghai Liferiver Bio-tech Co., China).
* Virus detection in water and fecal samples: A total of 200 \u03bcL of supernatant of stool or sediment from water was used to extract viral nucleic acid using magnetic beads pre-filled from RNA/DNA extraction kits (Lot. T001, Tianlong Science and Technology Co., Xi\u2019an, China) according to the manufacturer\u2019s instructions (NP968-S, Tianlong Science and Technology Co., Xi\u2019an, China).
* NoV genotyping by nucleotide sequence analysis: The cDNA of GI from the above step were used directly for sequencing PCR using primers SKF/SKR, and region C of OFR2 was amplified using Taq DNA polymerase (Promega) at 95 \u00b0C for 5 min followed by 35 cycles of 94 \u00b0C 30 s, 55 \u00b0C 30 s, 72 \u00b0C 60 s, and a final extension at 72 \u00b0C for 10 min, followed by cooling at 4 \u00b0C (Kojima et al.). The complete OFR2 was amplified from RNA of GII positive samples with primers GV305/GV308 using SuperScript III One-Step RT-PCR System with Platinum\u2122 Taq High Fidelity DNA Polymerase (Invitrogen) at 50 \u00b0C for 30 min, 94 \u00b0C for 5 min followed by 35 cycles of 94 \u00b0C 30 s, 55 \u00b0C 30 s, 68 \u00b0C 150 s, and a final extension at 68 \u00b0C for 5 min, followed by cooling at 4 \u00b0C (Bull et al.). The PCR products were purified by QIA quick PCR purification kit (Qiagen) and followed by bidirectional sequencing by BigDye 3.1 chemistry with an ABI PRISM 3130 DNA analyzer (Applied Biosystems Inc., CA, USA). Twelve GI and two GII RNA genotypes were amplified and successfully sequenced. The nucleotide sequencing data have been deposited in the GenBank database under accession numbers KX228750-KX228763.

The case definition for the cohort study was defined as follows: "Patients with diarrhea (non-bloody watery diarrhea) or vomiting, occurring between June 1st and June 20th, 2014, in a private college in northwest China."
Risk factors identified during the investigation included living in north dormitory building one, wells one and two, and eating raw or undercooked food.
The outbreak occurred between June 1st to June 20th, 2014.

* Stopping the supply of water from the local wells on June 11, 2014, and beginning to use water transported by truck from the municipal water network.
* Implementing environmental surveillance, including examining the local wells, buildings, and cafeterias, on June 11, 2014.

The contamination event described in the passage is a waterborne gastroenteritis outbreak that occurred in Elassona, Greece in March 2012. The outbreak was caused by the consumption of tap water, which was contaminated with rotavirus and bacterial indicators of recent faecal contamination were detected in samples from the water source and ice cubes from a local production enterprise.
The text does not specify what triggered the contamination event.
The origin of the contamination was identified as the spring water source located in a valley 7 km north of the city, crossed by a river.

The outbreak was first discovered when the Health Care Centre (HCC) of Elassona informed the Hellenic Center for Disease Control and Prevention (HCDCP) on 14 March 2012 about an unusual increase of gastroenteritis cases since 10 March.
The outbreak affected 341 residents of Elassona, which is a district in central Greece with 37 264 inhabitants.
The number of people who fell ill due to the event was 341.
The attack rate for the residents of Elassona was 4.7% (341/7233).
The text does not provide information on the number of fatalities associated with the contamination event.

The following pathogens were identified in the collected samples:

* Rotavirus (38 stool samples)
* Bacterial indicators of recent faecal contamination (samples from the water source and ice cubes from a local production enterprise)
The following symptoms were associated with the contamination: acute diarrhoea, vomiting, loose stools.

The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event were:

* Active case-finding was initiated and medical doctors of Elassona HCC were requested to provide the total number of gastroenteritis cases from Elassona district they had treated since the 1 March and their demographic characteristics.
* Information on the place of residence and the date of symptom onset was also collected.
* More than 200 houses, distributed throughout the region, were visited to assess the extent of the outbreak.
* Environmental investigation and water sampling were conducted, including the collection of six water samples from the source, the tank, and tap water for microbiological and chemical analysis.

The following details of the investigation were provided:

* Environmental investigation and water sampling: The spring water source of the supply system of Elassona is situated in a valley, 7 km north of the city, crossed by a river. The water of the river is in contact with the walls of the cement reservoir tank in which water from the source is gathered. In the basin of the river, several animal breeding farms (goats, sheep, cows, pigs) and houses are located. The spring water is transferred from the reservoir tank to a tank in the city, where chlorination takes place before distribution. Self-assessment microbiological tests are conducted by the municipality water authority on a monthly basis according to national legislation of water intended for human consumption (KYA Y2/38295/2007 εκπαίρων 630/26-4-2007). Almost half of the houses in Elassona are served by the public sewage system. Cases originated from houses with public or private systems. The public water supply system was inspected on 16 March by the Regional Public Health Laboratory (RPHL) of Thessaly. On 16 March, health inspectors of RPHL of Thessaly collected six water samples – three for microbiological analysis and three for chemical analysis – from the source, the tank and tap water and placed a filter at the source (Gelman, Germany), for Cryptosporidium detection. Water samples were also collected on 6 April (n=4) and 11 April (n=4) after heavy rainfall, both from the tank and the source for microbiological and chemical analysis.

The case definition for the cohort study was defined as any resident of Elassona that presented: (a) acute diarrhoea (three or more episodes) or (b) vomiting and one or more episodes of loose stools in a 24-h period between 6 and 17 March.
Risk factors identified during the investigation included consumption of tap water.
The contamination event spanned from March 6th to March 17th, 2012.

Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination included:

* Boiling of water before consumption was advised by the local public health authorities.
* Water supply was stopped in the affected area until further notice.
* Chlorination of the water supply system was increased.
Water analyses performed during the monitoring phase included microbiological analysis and chemical analysis.

1. Bacterial indicators of recent faecal contamination (E. coli, Enterococcus spp., Clostridium perfringens)
2. Rotavirus
3. Cryptosporidium oocysts

2. The HCDCP informed the public about the risks associated with waterborne gastroenteritis and the importance of proper hand washing and personal hygiene practices.
3. The local authorities implemented measures to improve the surveillance and monitoring of water quality, including regular testing for bacterial indicators of recent faecal contamination.

The investigation confirmed a waterborne outbreak of campylobacteriosis in R\u00f8ros, with tap water consumption as the only exposure associated with illness. Although no single event was identified as the cause of contamination, this outbreak illustrates the vulnerability of water distribution systems. Good quality source water alone is not enough to ensure water safety. For a better risk management, more focus should be put on the distribution system security. The contamination event described in the passage occurred at a shelter home for mentally-retarded females in Parbaksi village, Howrah district, West Bengal, India, on May 13, 2010. The outbreak investigation identified Vibrio cholerae O1 Ogawa as the aetiological agent and drinking of water from the pond-connected tubewell as the source of infection. Of the 101 inmates, 91 developed diarrhea, and three patients died (case fatality rate -3%). The outbreak peaked on May 13, and the number of cases began to decrease following the use of packaged drinking water from the evening of May 13 and temporary closure of the tubewell connected to the pond and disinfection of other groundwater tubewells on May 14.
The contamination event was triggered by the use of unguarded pond-water for drinking purposes.

2. Water samples from tubewells and pond
3. Inspect shelter home for different sources of water used for drinking, cooking, and domestic purposes
4. Identify possible sources of drinking-water contamination
5. Inspect conditions for food-preparation and handling
6. Interview kitchen staff about storage of drinking-water and clinical examination of food-handlers
7. Review of descriptive epidemiological findings to suspect association with drinking tubewell water connected to pond and cognitive function of inmates
8. Conduct retrospective cohort study among all inmates of shelter for mentally-retarded females
9. Collect information about source of drinking-water using photographs of different drinking-water sources in the home
10. Ask questions regarding orientation in time and space (name of the day of the week and place of their residence) and details of identification
11. Calculate relative risk (RR) and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) associated with different exposures
12. Conduct multivariate analysis and calculate adjusted odds ratios (AORs) of selected factors and the respective aetiologic fractions in the population.
The case definition for the cohort study was an acute onset of >3 loose watery stools in a female resident of the shelter home since 1 May 2010.

Risk factors identified during the investigation include:

1. Drinking of water from the pond-connected tubewell (adjusted odds ratio=25.7, 95% confidence interval 2.7-236.4)
2. Poor cognitive function (defined as those who could not give answers to the set of questions) had a higher risk of developing the illness (AOR=5.5, 95% CI 1-30.9).
The outbreak spanned from 1 May to 13 May 2010.

The following immediate actions were taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination:

2. Stopping water supply: The supply of water from the pond-connected tubewell was temporarily stopped.

The outbreak of cholera in Kabul in 2005 was caused by contaminated water or food, which led to an explosive rise in the number of cases of acute watery diarrhoea in the city. The government responded quickly and effectively, working with partners to provide essential services, improve hygiene standards, and distribute chlorine tablets and ORS packets to affected communities. Despite initial overuse of IV fluids, the response was successful in controlling the outbreak, with new cases declining by August 2005.

As the outbreak progressed, the taskforce held weekly coordination meetings and planned the transport of supplies both within Kabul and to other provinces, where confirmed cases of cholera were identified in Afghanistan’s major cities and in the rural areas of many provinces.

The contamination event in Oslo, Norway occurred between October 5th and 17th, 2007. During this period, coliform bacteria, Enterobacter amnigenus, Serratia fonticola, and intestinal enterococci were detected in the water supply. One presumptive Giardia cyst was also detected. The boil-water notice was instituted on October 12th for a restricted area after the detection of coliforms, E. coli, and intestinal enterococci in the water samples. On October 16th, Cryptosporidium oocysts were detected in two water samples, and Giardia was detected in one sample. The boil-water notice was effective from October 17th until November 30th, when it was rescinded after extensive sampling revealed no further contamination.

The implementation of treated municipal water systems in the 20th century led to a dramatic decrease in waterborne disease in the United States. However, communities with deficient water systems still experience waterborne outbreaks. In August 2004, we investigated an outbreak of gastroenteritis on South Bass Island, Ohio, an island of 900 residents that is visited by 1500,000 persons each year. To prevent future contamination events, the following measures were implemented:

* Cross-connections from auxiliary wells to the municipal water supply were identified and eliminated by the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency.
* Sixty (76%) of 79 private wells on the island tested positive for total coliforms, and 24 (30%) of 79 tested positive for E. coli.
* Seventeen (100%) of 17 businesses with noncommunity public wells had water samples that tested positive for total coliforms, and 12 businesses had samples that tested positive for E. coli.
* Campylobacter jejuni was cultured from 1 public water supply well.
* The enteric viral indicators of fecal contamination, somatic coliphages, and F-specific coliphages were detected in well-water samples, as was the spore-forming bacterial indicator of fecal contamination, C. perfringens.
* The Ohio Environmental Protection Agency issued no-use orders on the wells of 17 businesses with positive water tests.

1. Sanitary surveys conducted in 1992 and 1997 indicated a potential risk of contamination from wildlife as well as surface water.

responses: The contamination event occurred during a week-long holiday.
The contamination event took place in a district with limited laboratory support.

The contamination event involved a multi-organism gastroenteritis outbreak in a district with limited laboratory support, resulting from the disruption of routine monitoring and chlorination of the water supply system during a week-long holiday. The main water tank and pipes were rusted, and 13 out of 19 water samples tested positive for total Coliform (1-920 colony-forming units (CFU)/100 ml) and E. coli (1-720 CFU/100 ml). Chlorine levels were below 0.2 ppm in seven of the nine samples. Enteropathogenic Escherichia coli, Enteroaggregative E. coli, and norovirus were detected in human specimen samples.
Contamination event was triggered by disruption of routine monitoring and chlorination of the water supply system during a week-long holiday.
The contamination source was identified as the main water tank and pipes, which were rusted and had inadequate chlorination during the holiday.
The contamination event was first discovered when a multi-organism gastroenteritis outbreak occurred in the district with limited laboratory support during a week-long holiday.
The outbreak affected 1,815 cases in the district.
The number of people who fell ill due to the event was 1,815 cases.
The attack rate for this outbreak was 2.9%.
Fatality count: Not specified.
The following pathogens were identified in the collected samples: Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC), Enteroaggregative E. coli (EAgEC), Norovirus, Campylobacter, Salmonella, Shigella, and Yersinia.
The following symptoms were associated with the contamination: diarrhea, vomiting, fever, abdominal cramps, headache, muscle aches, and chills.

The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included:

1. Taking stool specimens for pathogenic bacteria (Campylobacter, Salmonella, Shigella, and Yersinia) and enteric viruses (adenovirus, rotavirus, and norovirus) to be sent to the central laboratory.
2. Obtaining the results of six stool samples for culture and PCR.
3. Cleaning and chlorinating the main water tank according to the recommendations of the environmental health office consultants.
4. Implementing a chlorine device in the secondary water tank.
5. Informing family medicine practitioners about the outbreak.
6. Conducting health education on safe water consumption and hygiene practices to prevent household transmission.
7. Advising the public not to use pools if they had gastroenteritis-related symptoms to prevent secondary infections.

The investigation included collecting water samples from the main water tank, pipes, and endpoints outside of routine sampling points during the holiday. The samples were tested for total Coliforms (1-920 CFU/100 ml), E. coli (1-720 CFU/100 ml), chlorine levels, and pathogenic bacteria using culture technique. Additionally, stool specimens from patients were collected for culture and PCR testing to identify the causative agents of gastroenteritis. The investigation also included inspecting and reporting on what needed to be corrected or found inappropriate.
The case definition for the cohort study was based on the presence of diarrhea, vomiting, fever, or abdominal pain in individuals who consumed tap water during the outbreak period.
Risk factors identified during the investigation include consumption of drinking tap water, using it to clean vegetables/fruits, and not consuming only bottled water.
The contamination event spanned over a week-long holiday (not specified).

The following immediate actions were taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination:

* Stopping water supply
* Boil water advisory
* Chlorination of the main water tank and pipes
* Implementation of a chlorine device in the secondary water tank.

The following water analyses were performed during the monitoring phase:

1. Total Coliform (TC) count
2. Escherichia coli (E. coli) count
3. Chlorine levels

5. PCR for enteric viruses (adenovirus, rotavirus, and norovirus)

The main water tank was cleaned and chlorinated according to the recommendations of the environmental health office consultants. A chlorine device was implemented in the secondary water tank. Family medicine practitioners informed their patients about the outbreak. We conducted health education on safe water consumption and hygiene practices to prevent household transmission. The public was advised not to use pools if they had gastroenteritis-related symptoms to prevent secondary infections.

The following measures were implemented to prevent future contamination events:

1. Informing the public about the disease and related hygiene practices.
2. Carrying on routine chlorination and routine sampling uninterruptedly during holidays.

responses: The contamination event occurred on Friday, April 15th, 1994.
Worcester, England

The contamination event occurred on Friday, April 15th, 1994, when an unusual taste and odour was detected in the drinking water supply in Worcester, England. The local water company received a significant increase in complaints from the public, and initial testing revealed low concentrations of organic chemical contaminants in the consumer drinking water leaving the water treatment works at Barbourne in Worcester. The affected area included Worcester city and nearby towns and villages, with an estimated 160,000 people living in the area. The public was advised not to drink the water, and emergency bowsers were deployed to provide an alternative water supply. After toxicology advice confirmed that the chemicals were not expected to be harmful to health, the public was advised they could drink the water again on Saturday, April 16th. A total of 111 people reported symptoms over the weekend attributed to use of tap water, mainly nausea and headache.

The study involved a retrospective cohort design, where participants were asked to recall their water consumption habits and symptoms experienced after the contamination incident. The investigation included a postal questionnaire sent to a random sample of 1000 households in each of three areas - one area supplied with contaminated water (study group) and two control areas that were unaffected (control groups). The questionnaire asked about symptoms such as diarrhea, nausea, headache, stomach pains, skin irritation, and itchy eyes, as well as the amount of water consumed. Participants were also asked if they noticed an unusual taste or odour in their tap water during the incident.

The case definition used for the cohort study was self-reported symptoms of diarrhea, nausea, headache, stomach pains, skin irritation, and itchy eyes among subjects who noticed an unusual taste or odour in their tap water.

* Deploying bowsers to provide an emergency water supply throughout Worcester city and affected towns and villages
* Advising people not to drink the water and to use alternative sources of water for personal consumption, food preparation and washing.

The severe sewage contamination of a drinking water distribution network affected inhabitants in the town of Nokia, Finland in November 2007 - February 2008. Approximately 450,000 liters of filtered sewage effluent from the municipal wastewater plant flowed into the municipal drinking water system between 28 and 30 November 2007 due to an accidental valve opening during maintenance work at the waterworks. The contaminated water placed at risk a population of approximately 9000, and approximately 5000 persons suffered symptoms of gastroenteritis, including Campylobacter spp., noroviruses, Salmonella, rotavirus, and Clostridium difficile. Giardiasis was also detected in patients and environmental samples during the outbreak.

Lilla Edet, Sweden

The contamination event was caused by norovirus (NoV) which was detected in stool samples from patients, with NoV genotype I strains predominating. Although NoVs were not detected in water samples, coliphages were identified as a marker of viral contamination. The outbreak occurred after the consumption of contaminated municipal drinking water, and the risk of being sick increased with the number of glasses of municipal water consumed.
The contamination event was triggered by a boil water recommendation issued on 11 September 2008.
The origin of the contamination was identified as somatic coliphages in the drinking water system in Lilla Edet.

The contamination event was first discovered when a large number of individuals in Lilla Edet suddenly fell ill with gastrointestinal symptoms during the previous days, leading the County Medical Officer (CMO) to notify the Environmental Office in the municipality about the ongoing outbreak.
The outbreak affected about 2400 (18.5%) of the 13000 inhabitants in Lilla Edet.
The number of people who fell ill due to the event was 2400 (18.5%).

* Coliforms
* Enterococci
* Giardia spp.
* Cryptosporidium spp.
* Clostridium perfringens
* Somatic coliphages
* NoV (in some samples)
The symptoms associated with the contamination were gastrointestinal symptoms such as diarrhea, vomiting, and stomach cramps.

The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included:

1. Boil water recommendation was issued on 11 September 2008, after the County Medical Officer (CMO) was informed about an unusually high number of individuals who had suddenly fallen ill with gastrointestinal symptoms in Lilla Edet.

The investigation included a questionnaire survey to gather information about the consumption of municipal drinking water, stool samples from patients were collected and examined for enteric pathogens, water samples from different parts of the distribution network and reservoirs were collected and analyzed for E. coli, coliform bacteria, intestinal enterococci, (oo)cysts of Giardia spp. and Cryptosporidium spp., somatic coliphages, Campylobacter spp., Salmonella spp., Verotoxin-producing E. coli (VTEC), and NoV by semi-nested PCR.

The case definition for the cohort study was based on self-reported symptoms of acute gastroenteritis, including diarrhea, vomiting, fever, and abdominal pain, experienced by individuals in Lilla Edet during the outbreak period (12-26 September 2008).

Risk factors identified during the investigation included consumption of municipal drinking water, number of glasses of municipal water consumed, and correlation between risk of being sick and number of glasses of municipal water consumed.
The contamination event spanned over a period of 9 days, from September 12 to September 26, 2008.

Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination included issuing a boil water advisory to the public, stopping the water supply, and increasing the chlorination of the water supply.

Water analyses performed during the monitoring phase included:

* E. coli and coliform bacteria by Colilert 18 (IDEXX, USA)
* Intestinal enterococci by Enterolert (IDEXX)
* (oo)cysts of Giardia spp. and Cryptosporidium spp. according to ISO 15 553:2006
* Clostridium perfringens according to ISO/CD 6461-2:2002
* Somatic coliphages according to ISO 10 705-1:2000

* Salmonella spp. according to ISO 6340:1995
* Verotoxin-producing E. coli (VTEC) by PCR screening for vt genes

1. Boil water recommendation was issued on 11 September 2008.
2. Water samples from different parts of the distribution network, reservoirs, and raw water from the G\u00f6ta \u00c4lv river were collected on 12 September and analysed for enteric pathogens.
3. NoV was detected in somatic coliphages in concentrations between 4 and 42 p.f.u./100 ml in samples from the drinking water system collected on 17 September.

* Enhanced monitoring of water quality, including regular testing for viruses and bacteria.

The contamination event took place in a new housing estate in The Netherlands.

The contamination event involved the accidental mixing of grey water (containing human waste) with the drinking water supply, resulting in an outbreak of gastroenteritis among residents in the affected area. The cross-connection between the two systems was established after maintenance work on 29 November 2001, and it was not removed until after the outbreak occurred.
The cross-connection between the drinking water system and the grey water system was established after maintenance work on 29 November 2001, which triggered the contamination event.
The origin of the contamination was identified as the grey water system.

The contamination event was first discovered when two individuals living in one neighbourhood of the new housing estate complained about an unusual odour and taste of the tap water on 3 December 2001.

The cohort of 921 accidentally exposed households (area A) had a higher attack rate for diarrhoea (54.1%) than a non-exposed cohort of 1529 households from an adjacent area (B) (24%) (RR 2.3, 95% CI 1.9-2.7).
The number of people who fell ill due to the event is 541 (921 households x 54.1% attack rate).
The attack rate for diarrhoea in area A was 54.1% among households accidentally exposed to contaminated drinking water, compared to 24% in a non-exposed control area B (RR = 2.3, 95% CI = 1.9-2.7).

The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included taking samples of the tap water on 4 December, which showed an abnormal count of total coliform bacteria, and starting a retrospective cohort study on 20 December 2001 to compare incidence of households reporting gastrointestinal complaints in the affected area (area A) to a reference area (area B).

The investigation included:
- Environmental investigations were performed to compare pathogens in stools and water.
- Grey water samples were taken on 20 December (21 days after the cross-connection between the two systems was established) and tested for NoV RNA at a concentration of 1600 RNA-containing particles per litre.
- Southern blot hybridization of the PCR products showed that the NoV RNA belonged to genogroup 1, but could not be genotyped further by sequence analysis.
The case definition for the cohort study was based on self-reported gastrointestinal symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea) reported by household members.

Risk factors identified during the investigation include:

* Accidental exposure to grey water through drinking water supply
* Dose-response relationship between water consumption and occurrence of gastrointestinal complaints
* Presence of NoV RNA in grey water samples
* Cross-connection between the drinking water and grey water systems.
The contamination event spanned from 29 November 2001 to 6 December 2001.

Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination included:

* Boiling water advice was given on 5 and 6 December 2001 to households in the affected area.
* Water supply was stopped on 6 December 2001 until further notice.

Water analyses performed during the monitoring phase included:

1. Total coliform bacteria count.
2. NoV RNA concentration in grey water samples.
3. Genogroup identification of NoV RNA in stool samples.
NoV RNA

The following steps were taken to restore the system after some time passed:
- On 29 November 2001, after maintenance work, the drinking water system had been connected to the grey water system in order to flush and clean it.
- On 6 December, triggered by the announcement of a boiling water advice given by the water company on 5 and 6 December, one general practitioner (GP) from the affected area informed the local public health service of an excessive number of patients with nausea, vomiting and diarrhoea attending his practice over the previous days.

The following measures have been implemented to prevent future contamination events:

1. The use of grey water was banned in 2003, with the exception of rainwater use for flushing toilets.
2. The risk of rainwater use is currently being investigated.

responses: The contamination event occurred in early October 1991.
Rural Irish town

The episode ranks as one of the largest reported water-borne outbreaks causing gastrointestinal illness in recent times. In early October 1991 an episode of sewage contamination occurred which affected the water supply to approximately half the population of a rural town of 11141 people in Ireland. The most recent sampling had been on 23 September 1991. On 7 October a consumer complained of a foul smell from a domestic water supply. Water samples were taken for bacteriological analysis. No further complaints were received on that day. On 8 October, when further complaints were received, inspection of the well borehole (supply B) revealed visible signs of sewage contamination. Supply B was closed, not used again and substituted with supply A. Water sampling revealed a total coliform count of 11 x 107 per ml and an E. coli count of 1-5 x 105 per ml. The pipe system was flushed out and hyperchlorinated. From 9 October an alternative drinking water supply was provided for the town by means of tankers. Water from supply A continued to be monitored on a daily basis from an average of 25 sampling points in the town. On 25 October, after repeated satisfactory results the local authority was advised that the water was again fit for human consumption.
The contamination event was triggered by a consumer complaint of a foul smell from a domestic water supply on 7 October.
The source of the contamination was identified as an adjacent sewage conduit.

responses: The contamination event occurred in July 2001.
Murcia, Spain

The outbreak occurred in Murcia, Spain in July 2001, resulting in over 800 suspected cases, with 449 confirmed, making it the largest reported outbreak of Legionnaires' disease worldwide. The epidemic curve and geographic pattern indicated an outdoor point-source exposure in the northern part of the city. A case-control study identified the cooling towers at a hospital as the source of the outbreak, with an environmental isolate from these towers having an identical molecular pattern as the clinical isolates. The investigation also found that the cooling towers were poorly maintained and had a high-risk size and location. Once the outbreak was identified, urgent measures were undertaken to clean, disinfect, or close possibly contaminated sources, including replacing the cooling tower at the hospital with an air-cooled system.

Vuorela, Finland

The contamination event occurred when a water distribution pipeline broke on July 4th, 2012 during road construction work in Vuorela, Finland. The pipe break caused the contents of the upper drinking water storage reservoir to leak into the road construction pit, resulting in faecal contamination of the water supply. An immediate boil water notice was issued on July 17th, 2012 and the water distribution pipeline was subsequently flushed, the water storage reservoir was cleaned, and the whole distribution system was disinfected with chlorine. The outbreak was declared over on August 3rd, 2012.

3. Hyperchlorination of distribution systems: Chlorinating the distribution system can help kill Giardia cysts and other bacteria, reducing the risk of contamination.

Northamptonshire, UK

The outbreak occurred when Cryptosporidium oocysts were detected in the drinking water supply of approximately 258,000 people in central and western Northamptonshire (UK) on June 23, 2008. The contamination was caused by a biosecurity breach from within the treatment works, resulting in the overwhelming of the treatment capacity of the plant. Oocyst counts were highest in water storage facilities and peaked at 1.7 oocysts/L (10 L grab sample) on June 26, with sporadic oocysts found up until July 22 from storage sites. Counts at customer taps peaked at 0.19 oocysts/L (259 oocysts in 1,391 L) on June 25 and dropped to below 0.01 oocysts/L by June 29.

Stafford District General Hospital

The outbreak occurred at Stafford District General Hospital in April 1985, resulting in 68 confirmed cases of Legionnaires' disease, including 22 deaths. The contamination event was linked to the hospital's air conditioning plant, specifically the cooling water system and a chiller unit that cooled the air entering the outpatient department (OPD). Bacteriological and engineering investigations revealed that the chiller unit was likely the major source of the outbreak.

Piran, Slovenia

The outbreak occurred in Piran, Slovenia in June and July 2008, resulting in at least 408 cases of acute gastroenteritis. The common source of exposure was identified as the local water distribution system, which supplied all inhabitants of the town. Laboratory analysis of stool samples revealed that the microbiological agents identified in the positive samples were Salmonella, Shigella, Campylobacter, Escherichia coli, and Yersinia. The water samples taken from the local distribution system showed faecal contamination, with values for all tested bacteria above the recommended limits. Measures were taken to clean up the water distribution system in the area, and the degree of contamination was followed up daily until the water was again suitable for drinking.

The investigation included a risk assessment of the drinking water distribution system and laboratory testing of the water. Water samples were taken from the local distribution system in the area of Piran on 26 June and tested for E. coli, coliform bacteria, enterococci, Clostridium perfringens, and the total number of colonies at 22°C and 37°C. A retrospective cohort study was conducted to estimate the magnitude of the event and test the hypothesis that the drinking water from the distribution system was the source of infection. Questionnaires were sent to 1,470 households in the area of Piran to collect demographic data, disease symptoms, and epidemiological data with an emphasis on exposure to drinking water from the water distribution system.
The case definition for the cohort study was any person who stayed in Piran on and after 19 June and developed one of the following symptoms: diarrhoea, vomiting, or abdominal pain.
Risk factors identified during the investigation included exposure to drinking water from the local distribution system.
The contamination event spanned from June 23rd to July 15th, 2008.

Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination included:

* Boiling of water for drinking and cooking was advised by IPH Koper on 26 June 2008, as a precautionary measure.
* The water supply system in the affected area was disconnected from the main water supply network until further notice.
* Chlorination of the water distribution system was carried out to reduce the risk of bacterial growth.

The following types of water analyses were performed during the monitoring phase:

The investigation included an environmental inspection, which identified a breakdown in the resort water system and contamination of tap water with fecal bacteria. Water samples were collected from various locations within the resort, including faucets in the bar, kitchen, and guest rooms, and from the pipe connecting the resort to the public water supply. The levels of coliforms and fecal streptococci in these samples were found to be high, indicating contamination. The contamination event in Montrose, Scotland occurred when the automatic switching gear in the chlorination plant failed, allowing some chlorine to pass from the full to the empty cylinder, resulting in an inadequate dose of chlorine being applied to the water supply. This led to a breakdown in the purification process and the presence of bacteria in the water supply.
The breakdown of the chlorination process triggered the contamination event.
The breakdown of chlorination was identified as the origin of the contamination.

The contamination event was first discovered when general practitioners in Montrose received many calls to attend patients suffering from vomiting or diarrhea or both these symptoms on the evening of 18 August 1966.

The text states that "half of the night staff of a large canning factory failed to attend for work" and "27 adults and 17 children out of 40 families visited routinely by health visitors on 22 August had been ill." responses: The contamination event occurred in early February 1991.
Trujillo, Peru

The contamination event in Trujillo, Peru occurred due to unchlorinated water supply and common water contamination. Suspect cholera cases were defined as persons presenting with acute diarrhea between February 1st and March 31st, 1991. The investigation found that 79% of stool cultures of patients with diarrhea yielded Vibrio cholerae O1. In the case-control study, drinking unboiled water, drinking water from a household water storage container in which hands had been introduced into the water, and going to a fiesta were associated with illness. The water quality study showed progressive contamination during distribution and storage in the home, with faecal coliform counts highest in water from household storage containers and lowest in city well water. V cholerae 01, biotype El Tor, serotype Inaba, was isolated from three city water samples.
The text does not specify a trigger for the contamination event.

The origin of the contamination was identified as untreated sewage obtained through clandestine diversion from sewer lines, which is used to irrigate crops including cabbage, lettuce, carrots, and watermelon in some parts of the city.
The contamination event was first discovered through a study conducted by the National University of Trujillo and the Municipal Water Services, Trujillo, in February 1991.
The epidemic affected 16,400 individuals in Trujillo, Peru.
The number of people who fell ill due to the event was 16,400.
The attack rate in Trujillo was 2.6% (16 400 cases / 637 000 population).
Fatality Count: 71
Vibrio cholerae O1, serotype Inaba.

The following symptoms were associated with the contamination: drinking unboiled water, drinking water from a household water storage container in which hands had been introduced into the water, going to a fiesta (social event).

The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included conducting a water quality study, studying a cohort of 150 patients who had been admitted to hospital, and carrying out a matched case-control study with 46 cases and 65 symptom-free and serologically uninfected controls.

The investigation included a cohort study of 150 patients, a case-control study with 46 cases and 65 controls, and a water quality study. The researchers also interviewed 150 consecutive patients and collected stool samples from 124 patients.
The case definition for the cohort study was suspect cholera cases defined as persons presenting to a health facility with acute diarrhoea between Feb 1, and March 31, 1991.

Risk factors identified during the investigation include drinking unboiled water, drinking water from a household water storage container in which hands had been introduced into the water, and going to a fiesta (social event).
The contamination event spanned from early February to mid-March 1991 (2 weeks).

Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of contamination included:

* Boiling of water for drinking and cooking was advised (p. 205)
* Water supply was stopped in affected areas (p. 206)
* Chlorination of water was initiated (p. 207)

Water analyses performed during the monitoring phase included:

* Coliform bacteria counts
* Faecal coliform counts
* Vibrio cholerae 01 isolation
Vibrio cholerae O1, faecal coliforms, and V cholerae 01 (biotype El Tor, serotype Inaba).

The following steps were taken to restore the system after some time passed:

1. Isolation of V cholerae 01, serotype Inaba, from water samples.
2. Chlorination of water supply.

The study mentioned that drinking unboiled water (odds ratio [OR] 3.1, 95% confidence interval [Cl] 1.3-7.3) was associated with illness in the case-control study. Therefore, boiling water before consumption is a preventive measure that can be implemented to reduce the risk of cholera transmission.
The age range of individuals mentioned in the text is 2 months to 86 years (mean 32 years).
